s: Recorded in 1962 at the height of the folk movement, singers Mary Travers, Paul Stookey and Peter Yarrow gathered some original songs, and some inspired by Pete Seeger and simply enchanted listeners with their amazing harmonies and simple but highly effective arrangements.

s: In a manner that their studio albums never could, Peter, Paul & Mary's live performances indicate much of what shot the trio to fame and influence during the folk revival. They were witty, sincere, and engaging entertainers, with strong, smooth voices and a smart sense of vocal dynamics.

s: Primer disco de Peter, Paul & Mary, un álbum con todo el aroma de aquellos días en los que el folk era lo "más". Con sus magníficas voces consiguen que canciones de otros (Pete Seeger, por ejemplo), que interesaban solo a nivel de minorías, se convirtieran en auténticos hits.

t: Peter Paul & Mary - Reunion - Amazon.com Music
s: After Peter Paul and Mary recorded Reunion in 1978, they turned it over to producer David Rubinson and, with a tour in the offing, effectively walked away. Peter Yarrow was mortified at the result, which he says was drastically overproduced. He calls Reunion "our worst album."

t: Peter, Paul & Mary - Peter, Paul and Mary - Amazon.com Music
s: As a child, I learned all of Mary's parts (and wore out the LP). I was delighted to discover the CD. I still sing along. I love the energy in Early in the Morning. 500 Miles and Sorrow tell such sorrowful stories. This Train, Cruel War, If I Had My Way, If I Had a Hammer, and Where Have All the Flowers Gone are all among my favorite songs of all time. In all honesty, there's not a bad track on this recording. If you want to hear Peter, Paul ...
